Description: Can a P1 or P2 provisional driver legally instruct a learner driver?

Options.Description: No.
Yes; provided the provisional driver has held a P2 licence for more than 6 months.
Yes; provided L and P1 or P2 plates are displayed.

Description: To progress to a P2 provisional licence a P1 provisional driver must hold a P1 licence for a minimum period of

Options.Description: 12 months.
18 months.
24 months.

Description: If one or two of your wheels run off the edge of the roadway you should

Options.Description: Slow down gradually and ease back onto the road.
Slow down quickly by braking hard.
Increase your speed and drive back on the road.

Description: If there are no lanes marked on the road you should drive

Options.Description: Near to the left-hand side of the road.
Anywhere on your side of the road.
Along the middle of the road.

Description: How close can you park to another vehicle when parked parallel to the kerb?

Options.Description: You must leave at least 1 metre front and back.
You must leave at least 2 metres from the front only.
You must leave at least 3 metres front and back.

Description: Where there is parallel kerbside parking, are you allowed to double-park alongside a parked vehicle?

Options.Description: No, not at any time.
Yes, if delivering goods.
Yes, if not obstructing traffic.

Description: Do you have any responsibilities when opening a vehicle door on a roadway?

Options.Description: Yes, you must not open a door if you are likely to cause danger to road users or impede traffic.
No, any following traffic must stop if the door interferes with its progress.
No, there is no regulation to cover this situation.

Description: Are you permitted to park on a median strip or traffic island?

Options.Description: No, not at any time.
Yes, in daylight hours.
Yes, but for no more than 30 minutes.

Description: When driving at sunset or dawn on a dark day, what should you do?

Options.Description: Turn on your lights on low beam.
Keep your sunglasses on to cut down headlight glare.
Turn on your hazard warning lights.

Description: You are driving at night with your headlights on high beam. When should you dip your headlights?

Options.Description: When within 200 metres of the vehicle ahead or an oncoming one.
When within 200 metres of an oncoming vehicle only.
Never, you are allowed to drive with your lights on high beam at all times.

Description: Is it an offence to obstruct clear vision of your number plates?

Options.Description: Yes, at any time.
Yes, but it is legal for a towbar or bicycle rack to cover the rear number plate.
No, you are allowed to cover your number plates if you want to.

Description: Before driving on a freeway, which of the following should you do?

Options.Description: Make sure your vehicle has enough fuel, oil, water and the correct tyre pressure.
Take your street directory in case you get lost.
Take something to calm your nerves before driving.

Description: What must you do if you miss your exit on a freeway?

Options.Description: Continue until you reach the next appropriate exit.
Stop, and reverse back along the freeway to the exit you missed.
Stop immediately and turn around.

Description: As you leave a freeway, which of the following should you check?

Options.Description: Your speed.
Fuel gauge.
Windscreen wipers.

Description: Are you permitted to drive a car towing more than one trailer?

Options.Description: No, not at all.
Yes, if the combined length of vehicle and trailers does not exceed 15 metres.
Yes, provided you have held a licence for two years.

Description: What must you do when you are towing a caravan to help other vehicles overtake?

Options.Description: Keep at least 60 metres behind heavy vehicles or other vehicles towing caravans.
Drive at least 25 km/h below the speed limit.
Stop immediately and let the faster vehicle overtake.

Description: Are you permitted to tow a caravan with a person riding in the caravan?

Options.Description: No, not under any circumstances.
Yes, provided you do not exceed 60 km/h.
Yes, if the person(s) in the caravan are over 12 years of age.

Description: Before driving a long distance at fast speed or carrying a full car load, you should-

Options.Description: Check your tyre pressure, and if necessary, increase it to what the manufacturer recommends.
Make sure you have a street directory, so you know where you are going.
Have a large meal and a cup of coffee.

Description: If an oncoming vehicle crosses the centre line and is coming straight at you and you cannot stop, you should -

Options.Description: Brake, look for room to the left, sound your horn and flash your lights.
Slow down and hope that the driver will turn away.
Drive onto the wrong side of the road and hope the other vehicle does not do the same.

Description: If you are involved in an accident where your vehicle needs to be towed away and the Police does not attend the crash scene, you -

Options.Description: Must report the accident to the Police Station nearest to where the accident happened within 24 hours.
Do not need to report the accident to the Police.
Only need to report the accident to the Police if someone was injured.

Description: Stop signs or flashing lights at railway crossings should always be obeyed, because -

Options.Description: Trains are fast, heavy and cannot stop quickly.
Pedestrians might be crossing.
Car brakes often fail.

Description: You should not drive across a railway level crossing when -

Options.Description: Traffic is blocking the other side.
You are towing a caravan.
A station is nearby.

Description: You should use your right-hand indicator when -

Options.Description: You intend to move to the right, at any time.
You intend to slow down.
You are about to stop.

Description: When merging onto the freeway from the entrance, you should-

Options.Description: Look for a large enough break in the traffic and adjust your speed so as to fit into the traffic flow.
Sound your horn, turn on your indicator lights and move onto the freeway.
Stop and check the traffic behind you on the entrance.

Description: If you see a sign indicating road repairs are going on, you should -

Options.Description: Slow down and watch for traffic controllers and instructions.
Stop immediately and wait for instructions.
Maintain the same speed.

Description: You see a broken yellow line painted on the roadway adjacent to the kerb. What does it mean?

Options.Description: Clearway restrictions apply - you must not stop during the clearway hours.
You may at any time, park along this part of the road for 1 hour only.
Bicycle riders must ride along the yellow line.

Description: If you see a horse and rider on the road what should you do?

Options.Description: Slow down and give them plenty of room.
Sound your horn to warn the rider.
Speed up to pass the horse.

Description: A friend lends you a van that has seats for ten passengers. What type of licence do you need to drive this type of vehicle?

Options.Description: A car licence.
A heavy rigid vehicle licence.
A small bus licence.

Description: What are you required to do if you develop a serious medical condition that could affect your driving?

Options.Description: Once you become aware of the condition you must notify the RTA.
Hand your licence in at the nearest police station.
Tell your doctor and let him or her notify the RTA.

Description: A friend lends you his car. It is very noisy and blows a lot of smoke. He tells you the vehicle has been given a defect notice but it's still OK to drive it. What should you do?

Options.Description: Before you borrow the car check the defect notice to make sure it is legal to drive the car.
Borrow the car, but always drive it 10 Km/h below the speed limit.
Borrow the car but only drive on streets where the car will not be a danger to others.

Description: Your car registration expires today. You have your car inspected for registration renewal but it fails the inspection. What should you do?

Options.Description: After today you must not drive the car until it has been repaired, passed another inspection and registered.
You have seven days to have the car repaired, after which the RTA considers it to be unregistered.
Go to the RTA and ask them to renew your registration and tell them you will soon get the car fixed.

Description: You buy a car and find that the spare tyre is smooth; the tread is only just visible. If you get a puncture will it be legal to drive the car with a smooth spare tyre?

Options.Description: No, it's illegal to drive a car with a smooth tyre even if it is the spare.
Yes, but you must get the puncture fixed within 24 hours.
Yes, if the tyre is correctly inflated and the side walls of the tyre are in good condition.

Description: You borrow a friend's car and find that the position of the driver's seat puts you sitting a long way from the steering wheel and controls. What should you do?

Options.Description: Adjust the seat forward so it's right for you.
Put up with the discomfort; you should not adjust another person's seat.
Ask your friend for a cushion to place behind your back.

Description: You are driving on a freeway and realise you forgot something at home. You want to go back for it. Can you do a U-turn on this road?

Options.Description: No, not at any time.
Yes, any time.
Yes, providing you use the gravel joining roads.

Description: You have a six year old child with you in your car. You have just parked so you can collect a prescription from the chemist. You should -

Options.Description: Take the child with you.
Leave the child in the car.
Ask an older person sitting nearby to watch the child.

Description: You are in busy traffic and slow down for a bicycle rider. A driver behind you beeps a horn and pressures you to go around the bike and drive faster. How should you respond?

Options.Description: Resist the pressure, stay calm and overtake the cyclist when it is safe.
Overtake the bike quickly and speed up to stop the other driver becoming aggressive.
Go slower because the slower you go the safer you are.

Description: Generally, if you hear the siren of an emergency vehicle you should -

Options.Description: Pull over to the left until the emergency vehicle passes.
Immediately come to a stop.
Let the emergency vehicle pass and follow it closely behind.

Description: When there are three lanes on a freeway -

Options.Description: The right lane is reserved for overtaking.
The right lane is for emergency vehicles only.
The right lane is for avoiding most traffic.
